rsbNotes.title: Judges 4:2
rsbNotes.text: 4:2 Jabin. This Jabin is a descendant of the Jabin mentioned in Josh. 11:1–9.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 4:4
rsbNotes.text: 4:4 Deborah, a prophetess, the wife of Lappidoth. Lit. “a woman, a prophetess, the wife of Lappidoth.” The emphasis is that a woman is the leader in Israel. Deborah, a prophetess, is introduced at the point where the narrator usually mentions the deliverer (6:8 note).

rsbNotes.title: Judges 4:5
rsbNotes.text: 4:5 sit . . . for judgment. That is, she was a magistrate, handing down legal decisions.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 4:6
rsbNotes.text: 4:6 Mount Tabor. This was a rounded hillock standing isolated on the north side of the plain in the Jezreel Valley.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 4:7
rsbNotes.text: 4:7 river Kishon. The river Kishon was near the base of Mount Tabor and was virtually dry for much of the year (v. 15 note).

rsbNotes.title: Judges 4:8
rsbNotes.text: 4:8 If you will go. Barak was asking Deborah to risk her life to verify the truth of her words, and he was also asking a woman to do what he had been assigned to do. From his point of view the mission was suicidal, since the exposed Mount Tabor could easily be surrounded by the chariots of Sisera, cutting off any escape. Barak’s faith was not equal to this danger.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 4:9
rsbNotes.text:
4:9 will not lead to your glory. Barak was punished for doubting (v. 8).

for the Lord will sell Sisera into the hand of a woman. The enemy will not be delivered to Barak, but to a woman. As God would have it, Jael (v.17) will succeed where faithless Barak will fail (vv. 18–22).

rsbNotes.title: Judges 4:10
rsbNotes.text: 4:10 Zebulun and Naphtali. See 5:13–18.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 4:13
rsbNotes.text: 4:13 river Kishon. See vv. 7, 15.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 4:14
rsbNotes.text: 4:14 the Lord has given Sisera. Deborah confirms her word from the Lord (v. 7).

rsbNotes.title: Judges 4:15
rsbNotes.text: 4:15 the Lord routed. From Deborah’s song we learn that the Lord sent rain that would cause flash floods, trapping the chariots.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 4:18–21
rsbNotes.text: 4:18–21 See 5:24–27 for the poetic account.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 4:21
rsbNotes.text: 4:21 drove the peg. No motive is given for Jael’s action. A woman killed Sisera, and the Lord’s word to Barak was fulfilled (v. 9). Women were not normally warriors, and it was considered shameful to die at the hands of a woman (9:53–54).

rsbNotes.title: Judges 5
rsbNotes.text: 5:1–32 “The Song of Deborah” is famous for its age and for its outstanding literary quality.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 5:2
rsbNotes.text: 5:2 That the leaders took the lead. Leadership is a major theme in Judges.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 5:4
rsbNotes.text: 5:4 from Seir . . . from the region of Edom. Mount Seir was the main mountain ridge running through Edom, Israel’s point of departure for the battles of conquest (Deut. 33:2). God is pictured as the mighty Warrior going before His people.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 5:4–5
rsbNotes.text: 5:4, 5 the earth trembled . . . before the Lord. God is pictured as a warrior who fights by means of the created elements. The portrayal of God as ruling the storm is doubly appropriate: by defeating Sisera with a cloudburst (v. 20) God refutes Baal’s claim to be lord of the storm.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 5:6–7
rsbNotes.text: 5:6, 7 the highways were abandoned. Israel’s failed leadership had resulted in chaos and foreign domination. It was not like the days in which God had been the warrior at the front of Israel (vv. 4–5). The roads were abandoned because they were not safe for travel on account of the foreign oppressors and robbers. No one provided protection.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 5:7
rsbNotes.text: 5:7 a mother in Israel. The princes would not lead (implied by v. 2), but a woman was raised up to lead Israel. Contrast this “mother in Israel” with the despairing mother of Sisera (v. 28).

rsbNotes.title: Judges 5:8
rsbNotes.text: 5:8 When new gods were chosen, then war was in the gates. This is a poetic representation of the cycle of sin and punishment (2:11–19). Idolatry brings suffering to the city.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 5:9
rsbNotes.text: 5:9 offered themselves. Later in the song there is a pointed comparison of those who volunteered to fight and those who for some reason refused (v. 13–23).

rsbNotes.title: Judges 5:10
rsbNotes.text: 5:10 ride on white donkeys. Donkeys were ridden by nobility; the song is addressed to the princes mentioned in vv. 2, 9.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 5:11
rsbNotes.text: 5:11 the righteous triumphs of the Lord. The Lord’s righteous acts are His intervention and defeat of His people’s enemies. These are His judgments in the earth (cf. Rev. 15:4).

rsbNotes.title: Judges 5:15
rsbNotes.text: 5:15 great searchings. The failure of Reuben, Gilead, Dan, and Asher (v. 17) to participate shows that Israel was not united.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 5:20
rsbNotes.text: 5:20 the stars fought. The participation of the heavens means that God was intervening, fighting as the divine Warrior from heaven. This text has been appealed to in history as biblical grounds for astrology, but this distorts the sense of the passage.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 5:23
rsbNotes.text: 5:23 Meroz. A city of uncertain location.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 5:24–27
rsbNotes.text: 5:24–27 This section of the song closely parallels the narrative of 4:18–22.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 5:31
rsbNotes.text: 5:31 rest for forty years. This standard conclusion ties Deborah’s and Barak’s song to ch. 4 (cf. 2:19; 3:11).
